title: Which technology for writing desktop software?
Tags: programming

inline_content.Text: Tags: programming

title: This post is inspired by
a question
a
http://discuss.joelonsoftware.com/default.asp?biz.5.829264.15
posted on JoelOnSoftware software business forum.

inline_content.Text: This post is inspired by
a question
posted on JoelOnSoftware software business forum.

title: To paraphrase: “I’m a one person coding machine. I want to write small, consumer oriented desktop software. Which technology should I use? Should I write cross-platform code or stick with one platform?”

inline_content.Text: To paraphrase: “I’m a one person coding machine. I want to write small, consumer oriented desktop software. Which technology should I use? Should I write cross-platform code or stick with one platform?”

title: It is a good question because the amount of available technologies is vast: C/C++, .NET, Java, Adobe Air, Cocoa with Objective-C, QT, wxWidgets and many more lesser known technologies.

inline_content.Text: It is a good question because the amount of available technologies is vast: C/C++, .NET, Java, Adobe Air, Cocoa with Objective-C, QT, wxWidgets and many more lesser known technologies.

title: I have an answer.

inline_content.Text: I have an answer.

title: Don’t write cross-platform code

inline_content.Text: Don’t write cross-platform code

title: The logic behind writing cross-platform code is deceptively attractive: if I target both Mac and Windows, I’ll sell twice as many copies of my software.

inline_content.Text: The logic behind writing cross-platform code is deceptively attractive: if I target both Mac and Windows, I’ll sell twice as many copies of my software.

title: However, at the beginning your biggest problem is that your idea hasn’t been tested with the market. Writing for a single platform is faster so you’ll find out sooner if your software is a hit or a flop.

inline_content.Text: However, at the beginning your biggest problem is that your idea hasn’t been tested with the market. Writing for a single platform is faster so you’ll find out sooner if your software is a hit or a flop.

title: If it’s a flop, the effort of supporting two platforms was lot.

inline_content.Text: If it’s a flop, the effort of supporting two platforms was lot.

title: If it’s a success: congratulation, you now have the money to invest in supporting the other platform and a much higher chance that the result will be successful as well.

inline_content.Text: If it’s a success: congratulation, you now have the money to invest in supporting the other platform and a much higher chance that the result will be successful as well.

title: Don’t delude yourself that a cross-platform toolkit will allow you to ship a cross-platform as fast as shipping a single-platform code. Life is not as simple as that.

inline_content.Text: Don’t delude yourself that a cross-platform toolkit will allow you to ship a cross-platform as fast as shipping a single-platform code. Life is not as simple as that.

title: Today Qt is the best cross-platform toolkit, a truly impressive piece of work. It is, however, limited by its legacy. Qt requires you to use C++. You’ll be much more productive using C# with WPF on Windows or Objective C with Coca on Mac.

inline_content.Text: Today Qt is the best cross-platform toolkit, a truly impressive piece of work. It is, however, limited by its legacy. Qt requires you to use C++. You’ll be much more productive using C# with WPF on Windows or Objective C with Coca on Mac.

title: Writing code takes only a fraction of time and effort needed to ship an application to end users. Other activities that you’ll need to do that also require doubling the time and effort:

inline_content.Text: Writing code takes only a fraction of time and effort needed to ship an application to end users. Other activities that you’ll need to do that also require doubling the time and effort:

title: testing the code on both platforms

inline_content.Text: testing the code on both platforms

title: writing documentation and marketing materials for 2 platforms

inline_content.Text: writing documentation and marketing materials for 2 platforms

title: learning how to market to both Windows and Mac users

inline_content.Text: learning how to market to both Windows and Mac users

title: learning to become an expert user of both OSes to help your users when inevitable support requests come in

inline_content.Text: learning to become an expert user of both OSes to help your users when inevitable support requests come in

title: What you need from a platform

inline_content.Text: What you need from a platform

title: Sometimes platform are chosen based on vague understanding of what they provide. I see no end of people who e.g. will blindly suggest Adobe Air just because it’s marketed as allowing cross-platform development and happens to get lots of buzz recently, without considering if the technical limitations of Air would even make a given application possible to write.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes platform are chosen based on vague understanding of what they provide. I see no end of people who e.g. will blindly suggest Adobe Air just because it’s marketed as allowing cross-platform development and happens to get lots of buzz recently, without considering if the technical limitations of Air would even make a given application possible to write.

title: Here are things to consider when choosing a platform for your software.

inline_content.Text: Here are things to consider when choosing a platform for your software.

title: Is it capable enough?

inline_content.Text: Is it capable enough?

title: Adobe Air might be a great technology for some applications. If you’re building a Twitter client, it’ll do just fine. If you’re building a novel compression engine, it’s not appropriate.

inline_content.Text: Adobe Air might be a great technology for some applications. If you’re building a Twitter client, it’ll do just fine. If you’re building a novel compression engine, it’s not appropriate.

title: By their nature, cross platform toolkits tend to target the lowest common denominator and don’t support important platform-specific features. Those fancy Core Animation transitions in your Mac app? You probably won’t get that from Java or Air or Qt. Support for Windows 7 task bar integration? Probably not there either.

inline_content.Text: By their nature, cross platform toolkits tend to target the lowest common denominator and don’t support important platform-specific features. Those fancy Core Animation transitions in your Mac app? You probably won’t get that from Java or Air or Qt. Support for Windows 7 task bar integration? Probably not there either.

title: Is it documented well?

inline_content.Text: Is it documented well?

title: This is not only about documentation that comes in the box but also about the availability of greater ecosystem. You’ll run into problems, bugs, things you don’t understand. It’s important to resolve those issues quickly.

inline_content.Text: This is not only about documentation that comes in the box but also about the availability of greater ecosystem. You’ll run into problems, bugs, things you don’t understand. It’s important to resolve those issues quickly.

title: Mainstream technologies like Java or .NET are documented in books from respected publishers, numerous blog posts and have communities where you can show up, ask a question and get an answer quickly. There’s much less of that for e.g Adobe Air or Clojure.

inline_content.Text: Mainstream technologies like Java or .NET are documented in books from respected publishers, numerous blog posts and have communities where you can show up, ask a question and get an answer quickly. There’s much less of that for e.g Adobe Air or Clojure.

title: Are there third-party libraries available?

inline_content.Text: Are there third-party libraries available?

title: You don’t want to write a zip compression or http client from scratch. Availability of 3rd party libraries that you can drop in your code and save tons of time is important. In that respect Java and .NET are unmatched. There’s lots of C/C++ libraries out there, but integrating them in your project will be harder.

inline_content.Text: You don’t want to write a zip compression or http client from scratch. Availability of 3rd party libraries that you can drop in your code and save tons of time is important. In that respect Java and .NET are unmatched. There’s lots of C/C++ libraries out there, but integrating them in your project will be harder.

title: Are other programs like the one you’re thinking about implemented with that toolkit?

inline_content.Text: Are other programs like the one you’re thinking about implemented with that toolkit?

title: Can you write a great text editor in Air? I don’t know, I haven’t seen one.

inline_content.Text: Can you write a great text editor in Air? I don’t know, I haven’t seen one.

title: The fact that Microsoft used .NET/WPF for writing editor in Visual Studio or that Eclipse is written in Java is a proof that a complex text editor can be written in those technologies.

inline_content.Text: The fact that Microsoft used .NET/WPF for writing editor in Visual Studio or that Eclipse is written in Java is a proof that a complex text editor can be written in those technologies.

title: Do you know it well?

inline_content.Text: Do you know it well?

title: Learning a new technology is hard. Even switching to a similar platforms (e.g. from Java to C#) requires a large amount of effort and time. All else being equal, use the technology you already know.

inline_content.Text: Learning a new technology is hard. Even switching to a similar platforms (e.g. from Java to C#) requires a large amount of effort and time. All else being equal, use the technology you already know.

title: Now for a final verdict.

inline_content.Text: Now for a final verdict.

title: Cocoa is for Mac

inline_content.Text: Cocoa is for Mac

title: There really is no contest: for writing Mac software use Cocoa with Objective-C. While Java or C# are more productive than Objective-C, you can’t beat the combination of tool support (XCode, especially in version 4, is doing a lot to help you program in Objective-C), documentation, community. It’s also the most capable, being the native language of the platform.

inline_content.Text: There really is no contest: for writing Mac software use Cocoa with Objective-C. While Java or C# are more productive than Objective-C, you can’t beat the combination of tool support (XCode, especially in version 4, is doing a lot to help you program in Objective-C), documentation, community. It’s also the most capable, being the native language of the platform.

title: .NET and WPF is for Windows

inline_content.Text: .NET and WPF is for Windows

title: While Java is close to C# in productivity, documentation and availability of 3rd party libraries, .NET wins by having WPF, better integration with Windows and being better optimized for desktop apps.

inline_content.Text: While Java is close to C# in productivity, documentation and availability of 3rd party libraries, .NET wins by having WPF, better integration with Windows and being better optimized for desktop apps.

title: WPF is what seals the deal: there’s nothing even remotely as good in Java land for writing UI code.

inline_content.Text: WPF is what seals the deal: there’s nothing even remotely as good in Java land for writing UI code.

title: Unsurprisingly, .NET is more capable than Java when it comes to all the little things you need to do to integrate with the OS really well. Things like support for Win 7 taskbar, reading/writing registry etc. I’m sure all that can eventually be achieved with Java, but .NET already has everything you can possibly need to make your app a good citizen in Windows.

inline_content.Text: Unsurprisingly, .NET is more capable than Java when it comes to all the little things you need to do to integrate with the OS really well. Things like support for Win 7 taskbar, reading/writing registry etc. I’m sure all that can eventually be achieved with Java, but .NET already has everything you can possibly need to make your app a good citizen in Windows.

title: Finally, Java platform is mostly used on servers and optimized for that. In that context, it’s much more important that an app runs fast in a stead state than to have short startup time.

inline_content.Text: Finally, Java platform is mostly used on servers and optimized for that. In that context, it’s much more important that an app runs fast in a stead state than to have short startup time.

title: On desktop, things like startup time matters and Microsoft cares about minimizing that, since their own apps are increasingly using .NET. Your apps get the benefit of Microsoft’s work on optimizing startup time.

inline_content.Text: On desktop, things like startup time matters and Microsoft cares about minimizing that, since their own apps are increasingly using .NET. Your apps get the benefit of Microsoft’s work on optimizing startup time.

title: What if you absolutely must target both platforms?

inline_content.Text: What if you absolutely must target both platforms?

title: What if your startup idea requires multi-platform support and you just got few millions in funding?

inline_content.Text: What if your startup idea requires multi-platform support and you just got few millions in funding?

title: It’s still better to hire two competent programmers, each an expert in writing software for one platform.

inline_content.Text: It’s still better to hire two competent programmers, each an expert in writing software for one platform.

title: I’ve seen very few successful products that target both Windows and Mac. I exclude titans like Microsoft or Adobe, who have extremely complex application and infinite amounts of cash to pour into development.

inline_content.Text: I’ve seen very few successful products that target both Windows and Mac. I exclude titans like Microsoft or Adobe, who have extremely complex application and infinite amounts of cash to pour into development.

title: Within the confines of small company, at best you might succeed despite sucking, like Libox (their Mac application doesn’t even respect Cmd-Q). All the runaway successes that come to my mind, like Evernote or Dropbox, did invest in a native clients for each platform they support, because their apps are their core differentiator (there are tens of note-taking applications out there or apps that allow to backup or share files in some way).

inline_content.Text: Within the confines of small company, at best you might succeed despite sucking, like Libox (their Mac application doesn’t even respect Cmd-Q). All the runaway successes that come to my mind, like Evernote or Dropbox, did invest in a native clients for each platform they support, because their apps are their core differentiator (there are tens of note-taking applications out there or apps that allow to backup or share files in some way).
